0.description: Caused by Xanthomonas spp., produces dark, angular leaf and fruit spots.
0.cure: Use certified disease-free seed, apply drip irrigation, maintain good spacing and airflow; begin protective sprays of copper + mancozeb or Actigard + copper weekly starting two weeks after transplanting; remove and destroy infected debris.

1.description: A fungal disease (Alternaria solani) causing bull's eye leaf spots on older foliage.
1.cure: Rotate crops 2-3 years, use resistant/tolerant cultivars, prune lower leaves, mulch, water early with drip irrigation, and apply fungicides such as azoxystrobin, chlorothalonil or copper at 7-14-day intervals from first symptoms.

2.description: No diseaseâ€”plant is in good health.
2.cure: Continue good cultural practices: proper watering, spacing, rotation, and monitoring to maintain health.

3.description: Caused by Phytophthora infestans, leads to rapid collapse and water soaked lesions.
3.cure: Plant resistant varieties, remove and destroy infected plants immediately, apply protectant sprays of copper or chlorothalonil weekly during wet, cool weather, disinfect tools and supports.

4.description: Fungal disease producing moldy patches mainly on leaf undersides in humid conditions.
4.cure: Improve airflow by pruning and spacing, avoid overhead watering, apply appropriate fungicides early, and remove infected foliage to reduce humidity.

5.description: Fungal disease causing small, circular spots with dark edges and light centers on foliage.
5.cure: Rotate crops, mulch, prune for airflow, remove debris, apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or related products on 7-14 day schedule.}

6.disease: Tomato Spider mites, Two  spotted spider_mite
6.description: Tiny mites that feed on sap, causing stippling and webbing on leaves.
6.cure: Regularly hose off mites, introduce predatory mites or insects, use horticultural oils or miticides, and avoid plant stress by proper watering and nutrition.

7.description: Leaf fungal disease forming concentric ringed lesions on foliage.
7.cure: Remove infected leaves, improve airflow, apply fungicides targeted for leaf spot diseases, and rotate crops to reduce inoculum.

8.description: Viral disease transmitted by whiteflies, causes leaf yellowing, curling and stunting.
8.cure: Control whiteflies using reflective mulch, insecticidal soaps or neem oil, remove infected plants, use resistant varieties, and practice strict sanitation.

9.description: Stable virus causing mottled, distorted leaves and fruit.
9.cure: Use virus-free seed/transplants, disinfect tools and hands, remove infected plants, and grow resistant varieties; no chemical cure exists.
